Sure! Here's a potential question for a math student: 

A certain radioactive substance has a half-life of 10 days. If the initial mass of the substance is 200 grams, what will be the mass after 30 days?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the half-life formula:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial mass is 200 grams, the time elapsed is 30 days, and the half-life is 10 days. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final mass = 200 * (1/2)^(30/10)
Final mass = 200 * (1/2)^3
Final mass = 200 * (1/8)
Final mass = 25 grams

So, after 30 days, the mass of the radioactive substance will be 25 grams.
